item.title: Empty Your Cup: Accepting Ignorance to Learn
item.description:
[caption id="attachment_1828" align="alignright" width="199" caption="Neal on Flickr"][/caption]

A university professor went to visit a famous Zen master. While the master quietly served tea, the professor talked about Zen. The master poured the visitor's cup to the brim, and then kept pouring. The professor watched the overflowing cup until he could no longer restrain himself. "It's overfull! No more will go in!" the professor blurted. "You are like this cup," the master replied, "How can I show you Zen unless you first empty your cup."

I recently moved to South Korea to teach English to kids for a year. Adjusting to the new culture has been both humorous and challenging; things that I usually consider very simple have become extremely difficult. Basics of living—eating healthy, exercising regularly, and even basic hygiene—have new rules and best practices that I just don’t know.

The result?

I’ve had to accept that I really don’t know how to do much around here.

item.title: What's the Worst that Could Happen
item.description:
[caption id="attachment_1789" align="alignright" width="300" caption="Elsie esq. on Flickr"][/caption]

My girlfriend and I have been planning to live and work abroad for the past year, and recently all of our plans completely fell apart thanks to a school that went back on our contract. The result was that we spent two weeks scrambling for another position, another job, or just anything to move our lives forward. For two weeks, we were in total limbo.
